summary.text: Patterns are the building blocks of Zen. They are used to generate patterns of values in interesting, concise ways. The first value passed to a pattern is either time
or a position in space
, or
, depending on whether the pattern is assigned to a stream's
`px`
`py`
, or
`pz`
property. Patterns methods can be chained together applying each new method to the value passed from the previous one in the chain.

Return the Pattern that instantiated this Pattern if it exists, otherwise return this Pattern.
Useful when using any of the dollar methods, which spawn new Patterns, allowing you to return to this parent pattern.

Return the original Pattern in the chain.
Useful when using any of the dollar methods, which spawn new Patterns, allowing you to return to the original pattern.

content.text:
```ts
s0.set({inst: 'synth', n: 50})
   s0.e.every(5)

   s1.set({inst: 'synth', cut: [0,1]})
   s1.p.n
       .$if(s0.e).set(57).$add.saw(1,16).$.$mul.range(1,2,0,0.25).$$
       .$else.scales('d-dorian', 16)
   s1.e.every(1)
```

A stream is a collection of patterns that can be mapped across time and space. A stream's position can be moved around time and space. When a stream triggers an event, musical parameters are determined by the stream's position in time and space. Similarly, when a stream mutates an event, all active events are mutated based on the stream's position in time and space.

Streams are available within your code as

content.text:
```ts
s0.set({inst: 'synth', n: 60}) // set the stream's default parameters
s0.p.lag.set(1).btms()
s0.px._modi.saw(1,10) // map the synth's modulation index across the x axis
s0.py._harm.range(0,10,1) // map the synth's harmonic series across the y axis
s0.x.range(0,16,1) // move the stream across the x axis of the canvas
s0.y.noise(0,16,1,0.5) // move the stream across the y axis of the canvas
s0.e.every(4) // trigger a middle C every 4 divisions
s0.m.eval(s0.e).neq(1)
```

summary.text: A Pattern for determining whether the stream should trigger an event

content.text:
```ts
s0.e.set(1) // trigger an event every division
s0.e.every(4) // trigger an event every 4 divisions
s0.e.bin('1000 1001') // use a binary pattern to trigger events
```

summary.text: A Pattern for determining whether to mutate all active events in the stream. Only mutates parameters prefixed with
, e.g.
`_amp`

content.text:
```ts
s0.m.set(1) // mutate all active events every division
s0.m.every(4) // mutate all active events every 4 divisions
```

summary.text: An object used to map parameter names to different keys. Useful for mapping to MIDI controllers
A Pattern for determining whether to mute the stream

content.text:
```ts
s0.mute.set(1) // mute the stream every division
s0.mute.every(4) // mute the stream every 4 divisions
```

summary.text: Patterns to be mapped across time

content.text:
```ts
s0.p.amp.range(0,1) // ramp amp from 0 to 1 across the cycle
```

summary.text: Patterns to be mapped across the x axis

content.text:
```ts
s0.px.amp.range(0,1) // ramp amp from 0 to 1 across the x axis of the canvas
```

summary.text: Patterns to be mapped across the y axis

content.text:
```ts
s0.py.amp.range(0,1) // ramp amp from 0 to 1 across the y axis of the canvas
```

summary.text: Patterns to be mapped across the z axis

content.text:
```ts
s0.pz.amp.range(0,1) // ramp amp from 0 to 1 across the z axis of the canvas
```

summary.text: A Pattern for determining whether to solo the stream. If true, mutes all other streams

content.text:
```ts
s0.solo.set(1) // solo the stream every division
s0.solo.every(4) // solo the stream every 4 divisions
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the stream's position in time

content.text:
```ts
s0.t.sine(0,16,1) // override the global t with a sine wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.x.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the x axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting all axes of the stream's position at the same time. Expects an array of values
A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.y.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the y axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.z.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the z axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: Set multiple stream parameter using key/value pairs
key/value pairs
The Zen class allows you to set global parameters. It is available within your code as

content.text:
```ts
z.t.range(0, 16, 1) // pattern time
z.bpm.range(60, 120, 1) // pattern bpm
z.s = 16 // size of canvas
z.q = 16 // frames per cycle
z.update = 1 // when to update the executed code, 1 is on the next division, q is on the next cycle etc.
z.set({reverb: 1, rsize: 0.5}) // set global parameters for all streams. Can be overwritten by stream parameters
z.p.n.scales('d-dorian', 16) // set global time parameters using z.p
z.px._modi.range(0, 1, 0.25) // set global stream parameters using z.px
etc.
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the global bpm

content.text:
```ts
z.bpm.saw(60,120,0.5) // set the global bpm with a saw wave between 60 and 120, over 2 cycles
```

summary.text: A Pattern for determining whether the stream should trigger an event

content.text:
```ts
s0.e.set(1) // trigger an event every division
s0.e.every(4) // trigger an event every 4 divisions
s0.e.bin('1000 1001') // use a binary pattern to trigger events
```

summary.text: A Pattern for determining whether to mutate all active events in the stream. Only mutates parameters prefixed with
, e.g.
`_amp`

content.text:
```ts
s0.m.set(1) // mutate all active events every division
s0.m.every(4) // mutate all active events every 4 divisions
```

s0.mute.set(1) // mute the stream every division

s0.solo.set(1) // solo the stream every division

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the global time. The outcome of the pattern updates the variable
within your code.

content.text:
```ts
z.t.sine(0,16,1) // set the global t with a sine wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.x.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the x axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting all axes of the stream's position at the same time. Expects an array of values
A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.y.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the y axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: A Pattern for setting the stream's position in space

content.text:
```ts
s0.z.saw(0,16,1) // move the stream across the z axis of the canvas with a saw wave between 0 and 16
```

summary.text: Get the current cycle. This is available within your code as

content.text:
```ts
s0.e.every(c%2 ? 1 : 4) // every 1 frame on odd cycles, every 4 frames on even cycles
```

summary.text: Set the number of divisions per cycle. Changing this value updates the variable
within your code.

content.text:
```ts
z.q = 16 // set the number of divisions per cycle to 16
```

summary.text: Set the size of the canvas. Changing this value updates the variable
within your code.

content.text:
```ts
z.s = 16 // set the size of the canvas to 16
```

summary.text: Set when to update the executed code

content.text:
```ts
z.update = 1 // update on every frame
z.update = 4 // update on every 4th frame
z.update = q // update on the next cycle
```

summary.text: Set multiple stream parameter using key/value pairs
key/value pairs

readme.text:
# ZEN3
Zen is a Javascript library for expressing complex patterns with very little code. It was written to take advantage of JS's flexibility and is primed for pattern interference. Zen allows you to map musical parameters across time and 3D space. Plot multiple trajectories around the canvas and trigger sonic events and modulations whose parameters are determined by the stream's current position in time and space.

Zen is designed to be used as a live coding tool and is available for experimentation at TODO. It can also be integrated into other projects requiring pattern generation. See section TODO for further guidance.
## Basics
Zen provides you with 4 const variables, 8 streams, and a global settings interface:
### Variables
* t: an incrementing integer representing time
* q: integer, number of divisions per cycle
* c: integer, current cycle. ie. floor(t / q)
* s: integer, size of canvas

### Streams
8 instances of the
class (see below), assigned to the variables

. Used to map musical parameters across each cycle or the canvas, and determine the stream's trajectory across time and space.
### Zen
An instance of the
class (see below), assigned to the variable
. It is used to update the global
values. You are also able to pattern
to override the global time and

to control tempo.
## Syntax
### Pattern
Patterns are at the heart of Zen, allowing you to create complex patterns of number values. You don't usually instantiate the
method, directly; they are properties of a
(see below) and values are obtained under the hood. However, to illustrate how patterns work:

#### Snap
Snap a sample to the number of divisions.

#### Dur, Lag, ADSR
All of these values should be given in milliseconds. If you wish to quantize these values to the project tempo use

```js
z.bpm.set(139)
s0.p.dur.set(1).btms() // plays for 1 beat, regardless of the bpm
```

### Stream
#### Time and Space
TODO: s0.x, s0.t
#### Parameters
Musical parameters can be mapped in different ways across a cycle, or across each axis of the canvas, using methods
. Each method returns an instance of the
class which enables you to map values in a variety of ways. E.g.

On each division of a cycle, each pattern is evaluated to create a list of parameters key / value pairs. Each method passes its value to the next in the chain, with the first value being the current time
. This allows you manipulate time or space using arithmetic.

```js
// offset foo by half a cycle
s0.p.foo.add(0.5).range(0,256)
// move across the x axis at twice the speed
s0.x.set(t)
s0.x.mul(2).range(0,s)
```
You can reference other streams' parameters:

#### Events and Mutations
Use a stream's
properties to trigger musical events - discrete synth voices - or mutations - the modulation of all voices in a stream. Each property is, once again, an instance of the
class, but evaluates the result as a boolean type, rather than a number. True triggers an event or mutation, false is ignored. JavaScript is able to infer boolean values from non-boolean types. As
is false and any value greater than
is true, we are able to pattern numbers in order to trigger our events.

#### Key Mapping
You can map alternative key names using the
property of a stream, which accepts an object. For example, to use more descriptive keys when sending midi messages, whilst still compiling parameters to use a
You may extend Zen by adding your own mappings in TBC. There is one map available:

#### Solo | Mute
You can solo and mute streams. Solo and mute properties are also Patterns.
